  The Early Show | CBS Evening News | 48 Hours | 60 Minutes | The Saturday Early Show | CBS Sunday Morning | Face The Nation 






Sunday’s 60 Minutes offers insightful 
      stories that advance and give context to two of the week’s biggest news 
      stories: the dropping of the Duke rape charges and the offensive comments 
      of radio shock jock Don Imus.
 
In our first story, correspondent Lesley Stahl is the 
      first to interview the three white former Duke lacrosse players, whose 
      indictment for the alleged rape of a black exotic dancer set off a 
      national debate on race, sex and privilege. Reade Seligmann, Collin 
      Finnerty and David Evans were exonerated at a news conference Wednesday 
      and now tell Stahl what it was like to live a year of their lives in a 
      media fishbowl and in a state of worry over an uncertain future. She 
      also speaks to the North Carolina Attorney General who made the 
      vindicating announcement and who investigated the case after the local 
      prosecutor’s questionable tactics forced him to recuse himself.  
      Attorney General Roy Cooper reveals the problems in the original case and 
      the inconsistencies of the accuser, who, he says, continued to tell 
      contradictory stories during his own investigation. "We started out 
      knowing we had a problem…and the way it turned out, it was much worse than 
      we thought."
 
Radio shock jock Don Imus is 
      off the air after his disparaging comments about the Rutgers women's basketball team.  
      Mike Wallace profiled him a 
      decade ago, and given the events of the past week, the story is especially 
      revealing. The profile, broadcast in 1998, provides a look back at 
      his rude and crude behavior, and includes a startling exchange about the 
      N-word.
 
In our third story, Bob Simon doesn't have to go to 
      the ends of the earth to find an unusual story, because he finds one right 
      inside a prison just north of New 
      York City. Violent offenders serving long sentences 
      now have a way to free their minds from the harsh prison milieu – a 
      college education in liberal arts. Murderers and robbers studying 
      classical philosophy in a class taught by a teacher from elite Bard College may be a strange sight, but 
      it does go to the heart of the debate for rehabilitation. As the 
      Commissioner of Corrections for the State of New York 
      says, "I think it’s the logical view of incarceration. Going to 
      prison is the punishment. Once in prison, it’s our obligation to make them 
      better than they were."
 
These timely stories and Andy 
      Rooney’s auto show adventure, this Sunday, April 15, on 60 Minutes at 7 p.m. 
      ET/PT.
